lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While emphasizing the devastation brought upon the natives of California by missionaries and the Forty-Niners, you mistakenly attribute the gold rush to John Sutter (Week in Review, June 9). Stefan Zweig, in his essay "The Discovery of Eldorado," published in Europe in 1928, makes clear that Johann Suter, in later life known as John Sutter, tried to prevent spread of word that gold had been found on his land. Gold impoverished the wealthy Sutter and cost the lives of all three of his sons.
